When a compensation clause in an employment contract is ambiguous and leads to a legal dispute, the outcome may depend on various factors. Courts and judges may consider the following elements when determining which party prevails:

1. Contract interpretation principles: Courts typically apply certain principles when interpreting ambiguous contract language, such as:
	* Construing the language against the drafter (in this case, typically the employer).
	* Giving preference to a reasonable interpretation that favors the employee if there is a genuine ambiguity.
	* Considering the entire contract to understand the context and intent of the parties.
2. Evidence of intent: Courts may look at any evidence that demonstrates the intent of the parties when they entered into the contract. This could include written or oral communications, negotiations, or industry practices.
3. Parol evidence: If the ambiguity cannot be resolved by looking at the contract itself, courts may consider "parol" (extrinsic) evidence to help clarify the meaning of the ambiguous clause. This could include testimony from the parties involved or other witnesses, as well as prior drafts of the contract.
4. Course of performance: Courts may examine how the parties have acted under the contract in the past to help determine their intent. For example, if the employer consistently paid the employee a certain amount, that may be seen as evidence of the intended compensation.
